text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits a complete revision for the management of web content on the IRS.gov Internet site based on interim guidance OLS-02-1218-0001 issued 12/3/2018.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This supersedes the August 10, 2006 revision. Interim Guidance on IRS.gov Web Content Management Procedures dated 12/3/2018, Control Number OLS-02-1218-0001 is incorporated into this revision.
All Operating Divisions and Functions
IRS.gov Web Content Management Procedures 2.25.101
) Purpose: This guidance outlines the new IRS.gov content publishing model and provides business processes and standards for developing, publishing and maintaining content on IRS.gov. (
) Audience: All Operating and Functional Divisions (

) Scope: The scope of this guidance is to establish Servicewide standards procedures for publishing information to IRS.gov and outline the new Content Publishing Model (ICPM). All guidance contained herein is limited in scope to publication of information on IRS.gov (excluding microsites). (
) Program Owner: Director of Online Services (
) With the inception of IRS.gov in
, IRS implemented a web content man- agement tool that allowed employees to create and update web content for IRS.gov through an editor without manipulating Hypertext Markup Language (HTML) code. (
) In

, the Office of Online Services (OLS) began an initiative, the Content Upgrade Project (CUP), to signiﬁcantly improve the quality of key content pages on IRS.gov. Through the CUP framework, OLS and business units laborated to eliminate duplicate content, rewrite content in plain language enhance the visual presentation of speciﬁc content topics. Follow-up data analysis indicated the changes improved taxpayers’ ability to ﬁnd, and apply the information they needed on IRS.gov. (
) OLS, as business owner for the IRS.gov website, also conducted a compre- hensive review of content publishing practices in
and

OLS interviewed a wide range of business stakeholders to better understand business unit’s practices. Assessments identiﬁed both strengths and weak- nesses in the business units’ processes for developing content for IRS.gov. Most importantly, OLS found that siloed practices limited cross-collaboration among business units to capitalize on best practices and shed light on nesses in an effort to make much needed improvements. (

) Without documented standards and guidelines for maintaining content on IRS.gov, the business owners were not always able to retain improvements the website. The assessment and CUP project experience clearly identiﬁed need for Servicewide standards and processes for developing, posting and maintaining content on IRS.gov. (

) This section represents the office of Online Services which operates under authority of the Deputy Commissioner of Services and Enforcement (DCSE), with “traditional” online centers of excellence including product management, content/editoral, web analytics, mobile, and web usability - all consistent with industry best practices. (

) This section represents roles and responsibilities which oversees content agement of IRS.gov, as well as new functionality development, and web site enhancement efforts. Below are the Office of Online Services • Deﬁning IRS.gov business and technical requirements with input from impacted Operating Divisions and Functional Areas. • Managing the technology maintenance and enhancements for the prise user community. (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Integrated Enterprise Portal - Web Services

Integrated Enterprise Portal - Web • Determining the overall look and feel of IRS.gov with input from Communications and Liaison (C&L). • Providing enterprise-level guidance and direction to the content agement community. • Providing support to the content management community for tools functionality related to IRS.gov. • Coordinating with C&L to ensure IRS.gov messaging and style standards are communicated and met by the content management community. • Coordinating with the Office of Privacy to ensure privacy provisions have been incorporated into IRS.gov content management and tions. (

) The Operating Division and Functional Area Executives (senior and director level) are sponsors of IRS.gov. Executive managers provide vision and direction for their content on the site. Responsible for their information on the public portal, these executives are accountable for identifying and managing their content requirements. Responsibilities • Championing IRS.gov strategic use throughout their organization. • Overseeing their content on IRS.gov to position it as a premier customer communication channel. • Certifying on a yearly basis that their content has been reviewed validated as current and relevant. • Providing leadership and resolving any issues or needs pertaining their organization’s content. (
) The office of Online Services uses analytic tools and user testing to track needs and behaviors of taxpayers and other external stakeholders related IRS.gov. (

Term Deﬁnition Accessibility (also “508”) All content, user experience and design elements must comply with the section 508 amendment to the United States Workforce Rehabilitation Act of 1973. All electronic content and functional- ity must be usable by people with disabilities. Alt Text Alternative text used to describe visual elements on a page to support accessibility for visually impaired users.

The progression of content for IRS.gov from concept to retire
ment from public view. Stages include: Initiate (concept, plan), Editorial (draft, review, edit, approve) and Production (produce, recertify, mark as his
torical, archive).

editing content for publication on IRS.gov. This includes the appli

cation of plain language compliance standards, the use of the IRS Style Guide published by Communications and Liaison, as well as editorial practices speciﬁc to posting information on IRS.gov that are contained or referenced by this guidance.

6 2.25 Integrated Enterprise Portal - Web Services Term Deﬁnition Information Architecture The structural design of a website and the information on it. The art and science of organizing and labeling websites, intranets, online communities, and software to support ﬁndability and usability. IRS.gov Content Publishing A model that deﬁnes organiza- Model (ICPM) tional roles, processes and tools to standardize and improve IRS.gov content for end users. Meta Descriptions A description or short abstract of a webpage. Metadata Information about IRS.gov content. It is data that is used to label, sort, ﬁlter or manage IRS.gov content. Microsite Supplementary IRS websites with specialized content, indepen- dently managed by business partners. Example: https:// www.stayexempt.irs.gov Narrative Text Narrative text is a phrase, sentence, or paragraph(s) on IRS.gov. Online Content Life Cycle The standard business process used to maintain content on IRS.gov from the moment it is conceived to the time the infor- mation is permanently removed from IRS.gov. Performance Tool A job aid. It presents information that may assist an individual with performing a task but is consid- ered guidance rather than a standard, policy or business rule. Policy A course or principle of action related to IRS.gov. A business rule that must be followed when publishing information to IRS.gov.
Integrated Enterprise Portal - Web Services
IRS.gov Web Content Management Procedures
A function performed by an indi

vidual. For the purpose of this guidance, roles may be formal or informal and performed in order to publish information to IRS.gov. Roles are a critical component of the IRS.gov Content Publishing Model (ICPM) and allow individu
als involved in the content life cycle to coordinate activities.
Integrated Enterprise Portal - Web Services

Term Deﬁnition Root Knowledge Divided into two main areas: Legal Guidance (Authoritative) - Content that picks up where the tax code ends. Explains the practical implementation of complying with tax laws and the IRS administration of those laws. Examples include Revenue Rulings, Revenue Procedures, Treasury Decisions, and Notices. Legally binding. Tax Administration (Non- Authoritative) - Content the IRS is required to make public under FOIA and section 6110. Includes Written Determinations, Chief Counsel Advice, Reviewed Field Advice, and Program Manager Technical Assistance. Not legally binding, non-precedential. Search Engine Optimization Activities to reﬁne content on (SEO) IRS.gov so the information is easily located by commercial search engines. SEO activities typically include adding data about information on the site (metadata) and employing editorial practices that help com- mercial search engines recognize the nature of the presented infor- mation. Secondary Navigation Located on the left rail on desktop displays or under the primary navigation on mobile, these link collections are speciﬁc to the larger content categories found in the primary navigation and help the visitor navigate to more granular content. Links are built according to the site’s taxonomy.

Activities to reﬁne content on IRS.gov so the information is easily located by commercial search engines. SEO activities typically include adding data about information on the site (metadata) and employing editorial practices that help com

mation.

Term Deﬁnition Site Structure The overall organization of mation on IRS.gov. Site is also referred to as the tion architecture. It number of different such as navigation, tion of certain types of information, and labelling information to search and ﬁltering on Standard A stated measure of assurance that must be to publish information to Standardized Text Text that is predetermined some way such as a that may be used across content items. Static File May refer to PDF ﬁles, ﬁles, or other proprietary such as Word that are in HTML format. Tagging The process of applying metadata terms to content for the purpose of mation to the user in the system. Taxonomy A controlled vocabulary label content for the audience. Template A method to format for IRS.gov and present tion to the end user. It used to format associated or to present speciﬁc types on IRS.gov. URL Schema A standard method of web addresses. User Experience and Design The process and outcome enhancing the customer’s faction with their visit to or applications. This aspects or elements the customer that make content easier to ﬁnd and stand.
The process and outcome of enhancing the customer’s satis
faction with their visit to IRS.gov or applications. This includes all aspects or elements perceived the customer that make the content easier to ﬁnd and under
stand.
Integrated Enterprise Portal - Web Services

Term Deﬁnition Utility Navigation Common links to content that reside in the header on IRS.gov, but are not found in the main navigation or in the footer. They provide direct access to content aimed at niche audiences, news, about us or help. Part of the global navigation. Vanity URL Redirects users to an existing webpage. Example: http://irs.gov/ freeﬁle redirects users to https:// www.irs.gov/ﬁling/free-ﬁle-do-your-federal-taxes-for-free. Web Analytics Statistical measurements used to identify behavior and traffic patterns for websites. Web Content Management The web publishing platform used System (WCMS) to maintain and deliver informa- tion to taxpayers for IRS.gov. Web Strategy The process of planning delivery of information to a target audience using the IRS.gov platform. Strategy involves planning the audience, audience goal to be addressed, topic, location on website, metadata for search and ﬁltering.

) Business purpose: IRS.gov is one of the IRS’s primary public-facing customer service channels. It provides taxpayers and stakeholders the mation and tools they need to meet their tax responsibilities. (
) Business Rules: The business rules establish criteria for publishing on the site. IRM
, Content Life Cycle, addresses the process.
, Web Standards, addresses the level of quality for publishing content.

Business Rules: The business rules establish criteria for publishing content on the site. IRM 2.25.101.4.3, Content Life Cycle, addresses the process. IRM 2.25.101.4.4, Web Standards, addresses the level of quality for publishing
IRS.gov Web Content Management Procedures

) To achieve these goals, the ICPM provides clear roles, responsibilities and step-by-step procedures and standards for developing, publishing and main- taining content on IRS.gov. It also establishes business rules and standards around the following aspects of the ICPM: • Content Life Cycle • Roles • Records Management • Content Redundancy • Accessibility • Editorial • Static Files • Search Engine Optimization (SEO) • Site Structure • User Experience and Design (

) The phased development of the future state ICPM process will require collaboration between OLS and key business unit stakeholder The initial iteration that goes into effect with issuance of this interim is limited in scope and includes: • Web Content Management System (WCMS) and Content Request System (CMRS) • Coordination between OLS and business units • Intake and analysis of content changes (

) The web is constantly evolving. Maintaining a high-quality site requires us to iteratively improve our organization and processes for content management. OLS will iteratively build out the future state ICPM in partnership with unit stakeholders to make sure new standards and business processes organizational goals as well as customer needs. Working with business holders, OLS will phase in reﬁnements to the ICPM and content process until it becomes a continuous improvement program. New guidance will be issued as the model is reﬁned and validated in cooperation with business units. (

) The foundation for the future state IRS.gov continuous improvement will be the end-to-end ICPM. The end-to-end ICPM content life cycle will begin when a business unit identiﬁes the need for new content or to content on IRS.gov, and will continue to apply until the content is from the site. (
) When completed, the ICPM will help business units create and maintain customer-focused content that allows the customer to easily complete the they have in mind when going to the IRS.gov website.

When completed, the ICPM will help business units create and maintain customer-focused content that allows the customer to easily complete the task they have in mind when going to the IRS.gov website.
Integrated Enterprise Portal - Web (
) The life cycle deﬁnes each step that digital content must go through from creation to sunset (or removal). Content (

) OLS manages the IRS.gov content life cycle and site organization and Business structure. The business units own the content and are responsible for its accuracy and ensuring it’s current. Additionally, OLS will review taxpayer behavior and feedback through analytics and other research methodology drive improvement to IRS.gov content, in collaboration with business units, order to enhance customer experience. (

) Content is deﬁned as any information that appears on IRS.gov regardless format. Examples of content include: • HTML-generated webpages • Images • Static ﬁles, e.g., Portable Document Format (PDF) ﬁles (see IRM
, Static Files) • Links (
) The content life cycle consists of three phases:
Initiate: The business identiﬁes an information need and submits a request to OLS
Editorial: OLS and the business collaborate to develop and review content
Production: OLS uses the content management system to fulﬁll the business’ request (
) Various roles play an integral part in each of these phases. (

) The IRS.gov publishing process involves the following roles, working in a laborative manner. Roles and responsibilities for each are described • Business Representative • Web Strategist • Producer IMPORTANT:Roles and responsibilities do not translate into position tions. (

) Responsibilities • Serves as the business unit’s liaison with OLS. Representative • Coordinates business unit stakeholders to support publishing needs. • Coordinates activities between the business and OLS. • Submits the web publishing request to OLS and ensures the complete and accurate. • Conducts regular reviews of business content. (

) Responsibilities • Serves as OLS’ liaison with the business representative. Strategist • Reviews incoming Content Management Requests for and coordinates within OLS. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
M

Submits the web publishing request to OLS and ensures the request complete and accurate. Conducts regular reviews of business content.
Web Content Management Procedures 2.25.101

Works with the business to coordinate audience, business drivers, taxonomy, content type, template, expiration date and any translation needed. Coordinates ﬁnal business unit customer approval before publishing content. Coordinates page treatment and visual design support. Evaluates and coordinates requests for changes to site organization structure. Regularly monitors, audits and evaluates published content to identify content improvement opportunities.
• WCMS system expert for content production needs. • Veriﬁes

compliance for all content. • Applies metadata, template and formatting. • Updates and creates translated pages as needed. • Creates friendly URLs and IRS.gov URL redirects (pending approval from management). • Conducts content reviews to ensure optimized search capabilities, content presentation and organization.

) All requests for content support must be submitted using the CMRS. After request is submitted, OLS will work with the business representative. OLS process requests in the order they are received. Normal requests will be completed within ﬁve business days for content modiﬁcations. New may take longer depending on the extent of the request (e.g., a request to update dozens of webpages, creating a landing page). For exceptions see section about Rush Requests. (

) Multilingual Content: Whether creating new content or updating existing content, the business must provide the corresponding translation. The business is responsible for ensuring multilingual content is consistent with associated English content. The web strategist will remind the business sentative they can coordinate translation and publishing with Linguistic Services. (

) IMPORTANT: When the business unit anticipates a large web project, the business representative must initiate a content request as soon as This will allow OLS to provide the necessary level of support, allocate resources and advise the business unit on the best use of web and strategies. (
) Examples of such projects include: • A new tax law • A new initiative • A business unit plans to reorganize a substantial amount of content (
) IMPORTANT: If the business unit wants to consolidate or signiﬁcantly ture existing content, OLS considers this a special project that will require
IMPORTANT: If the business unit wants to consolidate or signiﬁcantly restruc- ture existing content, OLS considers this a special project that will require
2.25 Integrated Enterprise Portal - Web
OLS web strategist. (

) Modify Existing Content: If the public still needs the content, but it is no accurate or does not comply with all established standards, the business resentative must provide updated content via the CMRS. There are two of content changes: • Update: Simple changes such as punctuation, grammar or a number. Changes of this nature do not need to pass through the full editorial phase. When the business representative submits a request, the web strategist will verify it and submit it to production. • Modify: A change to the message. This includes rewriting pages, matting pages or combining multiple pages. When a content modiﬁcation is requested, the web strategist and the business tative will coordinate and validate the changes. • IMPORTANT: For all publishing requests, the set to unpublish date be set to one year from the date it is published, unless the business requests earlier removal. (
) Create New Content: If content has not appeared on IRS.gov before, it is content. A paragraph added to an existing page is not considered new See IRM
, Business Purpose and Rules, regarding creating and publishing content. Examples of new content: • Web page • Static ﬁle (PDF) (

) Recertify Content: Content on IRS.gov must be reviewed annually, at a minimum, to remain active on the site. The business representative is sible for working with their subject matter experts to determine whether the content is: • Accurate: The technical details must be correct. • Relevant: Content on IRS.gov must apply to and be written for a speciﬁc audience, so the business representative must ensure that it still appropriate for the intended audience and still meets the intended goal (i.e., does it still help the audience complete its task?) • Redundant and/or outdated: Identify redundant content and/or content that is no longer valid. (

) OLS will provide periodic reports listing all content due to expire. Business resentatives will ﬁlter the report to identify their content and apply a to each item. Once completed, they will attach the modiﬁed report to a Management System Request. Below are the four dispositions: • Certify with no changes: No updates needed, authorize to push out unpublish date one year. • Certify with changes: Updates needed. IMPORTANT: If information regarding the Subject Matter Expert identiﬁed for the webpage has changed, even when the content is still accurate and relevant, the business representative must notify OLS via the CMRS to update the contact information for the Subject Matter Expert. • Archive: The business representative recommends that it be removed from public view (unpublish). Archived content will remain available to Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
M

IMPORTANT: For all publishing requests, the set to unpublish date will be set to one year from the date it is published, unless the business requests earlier removal.

IRS employees via the WCMS in accordance with the IRS.gov schedule and can be re-posted to IRS.gov if necessary. Mark Historical: If the public still needs the content but it will never be updated, the item will be marked as “historical content” on IRS.gov. Such content may include:
- Aging news items that still have some relevance to the audience

Remain viewable by the public on IRS.gov No longer require annual recertiﬁcation Will contain language indicating it is historical and no longer updated Possible reasons for identifying content as historical include:
The content establishes legal precedent, guidance or detail for tax or IRS rulings and procedures.
There is a legal mandate for the content to remain accessible speciﬁ
cally through the IRS website.
There is a legal mandate for the content to remain accessible to the public, and not having the content on IRS.gov would create cost or burden to the taxpayer and the IRS.
External communications products such as press releases, to
- External communications products such as press releases, to that the IRS promoted a speciﬁc tax topic/event/etc. (

) Rush Requests: OLS considers any request that must be executed the day to be a rush request. Examples of rush requests would be government shutdowns, natural disasters, tragic events and time-sensitive press Rush requests will be processed in order of the requested publish date. following are required to support a rush request: • Requested publish date and time. • Written business justiﬁcation, e.g., tax law changed, result of sioner’s testimony to Congress, etc. • Email message from the manager or executive authorizing the rush (attached to the request as an .msg ﬁle). IMPORTANT: For requests that require immediate assistance please OLS leadership. (

) The business representative, web strategist and producer will work Everyone agrees on the details of the request and the timeline. The representative will identify the necessary people from the business to the content and ensure its technical accuracy. The web strategist will nate the technical expertise from OLS to optimize the content and publish it the website. (

) Some content requests are more sensitive or complex than others. The strategist and the business representative will determine the scope and whether the request warrants a full project with a team and a plan. If the strategist and the business representative agree that the request is a they will assemble a project team and plan the project. If it is not a project, then they will move to the editorial phase.

) Rush Requests: OLS considers any request that must be executed the same day to be a rush request. Examples of rush requests would be government shutdowns, natural disasters, tragic events and time-sensitive press releases. Rush requests will be processed in order of the requested publish date. The following are required to support a rush request:
Requested publish date and time. Written business justiﬁcation, e.g., tax law changed, result of commis
sioner’s testimony to Congress, etc. Email message from the manager or executive authorizing the rush (attached to the request as an .msg ﬁle).

The business representative will identify the necessary people from the business to approve the content and ensure its technical accuracy. The web strategist will coordi- nate the technical expertise from OLS to optimize the content and publish it to the website. (
) Some content requests are more sensitive or complex than others. The web
Integrated Enterprise Portal - Web (
) This section provides information of the Editorial Phase. (

) The web strategist will work with the business representative to create or modify the content according to all standards for editorial, taxonomy, Content Engine Optimization (SEO), reuse and redundancy, and digital content standards. They will also ensure the content follows requirements of IRM
, Privacy Policy. (

) The content development process may require the assistance of additional OLS resources such as User Experience and Design (UXD), Taxonomy, and Analytics. The web strategist will coordinate these resources. (

) Once the content has been created or modiﬁed, the business will seek approval from the stakeholders. The business representative will and Review Content deliver the edited content to the web strategist. (
) The web strategist will review the ﬁnal draft to verify that it complies with standards. They will either approve the request for production or changes to the business representative. (
) The request is sent to the production team once the web strategist and business representative have approved the content. Content Request to (

) The production team is responsible for entering content into the WCMS formatting it properly for display on IRS.gov. Producers will pull content Phase requests from a queue. If required content ﬁelds are missing or the are unclear, they will contact the web strategist for clariﬁcation. (
) Producers will process requests in the following order: • Rush • Closest due date • Landing page • Earliest submission date (
) Unless the request is a rush, producers will process requests within ﬁve business days. (

) In instances where the request is to archive content, the producer will that no other IRS.gov content references the archived item. If any exist, they will update the CMRS with a list of the items. (
) For all content items that reference an item to be archived, the web will contact the business representative, alerting them that the links to the archived content will be removed. (

) The business representative must respond with a conﬁrmation or an within three business days. If a business objects, they should request an native. If they do not request an alternative, the web strategist will the producer to remove the links from associated content. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
M

The request is sent to the production team once the web strategist and business representative have approved the content.

The production team is responsible for entering content into the WCMS formatting it properly for display on IRS.gov. Producers will pull content requests from a queue. If required content ﬁelds are missing or the are unclear, they will contact the web strategist for clariﬁcation. Producers will process requests in the following order:
Rush
Closest due date
Landing page

Earliest submission date Unless the request is a rush, producers will process requests within ﬁve business days. In instances where the request is to archive content, the producer will that no other IRS.gov content references the archived item. If any exist, they will update the CMRS with a list of the items. For all content items that reference an item to be archived, the web will contact the business representative, alerting them that the links to the archived content will be removed. The business representative must respond with a conﬁrmation or an within three business days. If a business objects, they should request an native. If they do not request an alternative, the web strategist will the producer to remove the links from associated content.

The business representative must respond with a conﬁrmation or an objection within three business days. If a business objects, they should request an native. If they do not request an alternative, the web strategist will authorize the producer to remove the links from associated content.

) If the business representative makes the request, the producer will provide a preview before publishing. and Approve for (

) The business representative will distribute the preview to the stakeholders need to approve the content before it goes live to the public. The business resentative is responsible for collecting any feedback or approvals from their stakeholders. (

) If additional corrections are required, the business representative will provide them to the web strategist. Documentation must be provided detailing the rections. The web strategist will review the updates to ensure that the still complies with all standards, approve the edits and notify the producer. (

) The producer will update the content in the WCMS and indicate when it’s is ready for review. This process continues until the business representative receives approval to publish from all concerned stakeholders. (
) Once the stakeholders have approved the content for publication, the representative will certify and notify the web strategist that the content is approved for publication. (
) OLS will publish the content on IRS.gov and notify the business (
) WCMS Reports: The web strategist will provide a monthly report to the business representative that includes all content expected to expire in the on Content
days. The business representative will submit a Content Management Request for each item and follow the recertiﬁcation process (see Recertify Content in IRM

). If the content is not recertiﬁed by the business by its expiration date, OLS will unpublish the content from the site until a recertiﬁcation disposition is provided by the business. OLS will the business with a report of items that were unpublished due to a non- recertiﬁcation from the business. (

) Audit IRS.gov Content: OLS will monitor the content and overall health of IRS.gov and perform periodic spot-checks and audits. These reviews may include analytics-based usage, plain language usage or overall site structure analyses. The web strategist will deliver the results and any to the business representative for follow up and action as needed. (
) The Web Standards sections are organized around speciﬁc topics. The business rules are organized under each topic area. The Editorial section provides a starting point for business rules. (
) IRS.gov editorial standards establish guidelines for all written content on IRS.gov. Content creators and producers must package that information both editorial and web best practices.

If additional corrections are required, the business representative will provide them to the web strategist. Documentation must be provided detailing the cor- rections. The web strategist will review the updates to ensure that the request still complies with all standards, approve the edits and notify the producer.
) WCMS Reports: The web strategist will provide a monthly report to the business representative that includes all content expected to expire in the
days. The business representative will submit a Content Management Request for each item and follow the recertiﬁcation process (see Recertify Content in IRM

). If the content is not recertiﬁed by the business by its expiration date, OLS will unpublish the content from the site until a recertiﬁcation disposition is provided by the business. OLS will provide the business with a report of items that were unpublished due to a non- recertiﬁcation from the business. (

) Audit IRS.gov Content: OLS will monitor the content and overall health of IRS.gov and perform periodic spot-checks and audits. These reviews may include analytics-based usage, plain language usage or overall site structure analyses. The web strategist will deliver the results and any recommendations to the business representative for follow up and action as needed. (
) The Web Standards sections are organized around speciﬁc topics. The business rules are organized under each topic area. The Editorial section provides a starting point for business rules. (
) IRS.gov editorial standards establish guidelines for all written content on IRS.gov. Content creators and producers must package that information using both editorial and web best practices.
WCMS Reports: The web strategist will provide a monthly report to the business representative that includes all content expected to expire in the
days. The business representative will submit a Content Management Request for each item and follow the recertiﬁcation process (see Recertify Content in IRM

). If the content is not recertiﬁed by the business by its expiration date, OLS will unpublish the content from the site until a recertiﬁcation disposition is provided by the business. OLS will provide the business with a report of items that were unpublished due to a non- recertiﬁcation from the business.

) FAQs are a list of questions and answers relating to a particular subject. (

) Before creating an FAQ, consider whether the content is truly a frequently Asked asked question using call data, web metrics or other supporting (FAQs) the content isn’t a true FAQ, you should present the information using content format. (

) FAQs that appear on IRS.gov but have not been published in the Internal Revenue Bulletin are not legal authority and should not be used to sustain position unless the items explicitly indicate otherwise or the IRS indicates otherwise by press release or by notice or announcement published in the Internal Revenue Bulletin. (

) If the FAQ doesn’t meet these criteria, add the disclaimer below to all new FAQ content that isn’t included in the Internal Revenue Bulletin unless the FAQs indicate that they may be used to sustain a legal position. The dis- claimer guidance isn’t retroactive but may be applied to existing FAQ during your annual content review. • Disclaimer: “This FAQ is not included in the Internal Revenue and therefore may not be relied upon as legal authority. This the information cannot be used to support a legal argument in a case.” (

This section provides information regarding the Business Rules process.

All new IRS.gov content must be unique and associated to a relevant topic. When updating existing content, ensure you do not duplicate information that may already exist elsewhere on IRS.gov. Content must be current and accurate as this reﬂects the public perceptions of the IRS and can have legal implications.

) You may request the use of approved images in designated regions of IRS.gov, but the repeated use of a single photo in a high proﬁle location across multiple pages will detract from the user experience and OLS will such requests. Photos must also be relevant and add value to the content. OLS will ensure there is no copyright infringement for any images used on IRS.gov. (
) There are three categories of text content: • Standardized text • Narrative text • Root knowledge (

) Standardized text is predetermined in some way, such as a disclaimer and may potentially be used across multiple content items. You should link to tralized standardized text across IRS.gov pages, but you may reuse the text when required. If actual text is used, only one use of each type may within any single page. The authorized items are: • Privacy statement • Legal disclaimer • Outage message (

) Narrative text is a phrase, sentence, or paragraph(s). You cannot reuse, repeat, paraphrase or duplicate narrative text located on IRS.gov. Link to do not appropriate it. The authoritative source for a speciﬁc area creates manages the related content. All others must link to that content. This does not apply to press releases created by Communications and Liaison (C&L). • IMPORTANT: OLS may approve waivers of this standard in cases. (

) Root knowledge consists of legal guidance (e.g. Revenue Rulings) and tax ministration (e.g. Written Determinations) information. You must link to root knowledge documents in all situations. You cannot reuse, repeat, or duplicate root knowledge that is located on IRS.gov. (

) IRS.gov is not a repository for audio and video ﬁles. Certain existing excep- tions apply (ex. National Communications & Liaison). The authoritative business unit source for a speciﬁc area creates and manages their own and audio materials and maintains them outside of IRS.gov. OLS will then or embed these hosted audio and video materials. (
) Do not reuse, repeat, paraphrase or duplicate tables on IRS.gov. The tative business unit source for a speciﬁc area creates and manages the content. All others must link to that content.

Photos must also be relevant and add value to the content. OLS will ensure there is no copyright infringement for any images used on IRS.gov.

) This guidance covers records management retention rules for IRS.gov and the record of changes to IRS.gov published content. ) A records control schedule (RCS, aka records schedule or disposition authority) is a document that provides mandatory retention and destruction structions for what to do with records (and non-record materials) no longer needed for current Government business. The development of a records control schedule is not by choice, but by law. Federal law requires all to have an effective and efficient records management program. (

Creating content in HTML through the WCMS is the standard method for pub- lishing on IRS.gov. A “static ﬁle” is a type of content for IRS.gov that cannot be created or updated through the WCMS. Static ﬁles are created externally and uploaded into the WCMS to provide public access to the content.
Integrated Enterprise Portal - Web Services

) OLS will not publish ﬁles in proprietary formats (e.g., Microsoft Word, Point, Excel, etc.) on IRS.gov. This is to allow site visitors to access information without the need for a proprietary application. (

) Exception: OLS may approve ﬁles in other formats on an exception basis. Approval may be granted in cases where the business representative is rea- sonably certain their intended audience is able to access ﬁles in that format. For example, it may be reasonable to publish ﬁles in Microsoft Excel for software developers, but not for information targeted to the general public. (
) Note: Creating a static ﬁle alternative to a webpage is not acceptable. This considered redundant/duplicative content. (

) If the business representative believes they need to publish a static ﬁle in a format other than PDF, they must request an exception when submitting a Content Management Request. OLS will evaluate the static ﬁle and its In order to streamline the process of exception static ﬁle publishing, they should coordinate the development of the content with their web strategist. (

For example, the web will refer a static ﬁle that appears to provide employee guidance that may an Internal Management Document (IMD) to the Office of Servicewide Directives and Electronic Research (SPDER) for review. If you believe your content may be interpreted as a published product or an IMD, you should dinate with M&P and/or SPDER at the beginning of the content development process. This will allow your content to be published most quickly in the priate manner. (

) OLS will maintain certain metadata to improve search engine results for IRS.gov content. The items listed below are applicable to the WCMS. Web strategists will work with the business to determine the best use of the data to ensure the best possible results for search within IRS.gov as well as with external search engines.

strategists will work with the business to determine the best use of the data ensure the best possible results for search within IRS.gov as well as with external search engines. • Page Meta Descriptions: This is the text that often will appear in results for this page. It must be no longer than

characters and include keywords as appropriate. Each page on IRS.gov should unique meta description. • Page Meta Title: This text displays in the title bar of a visitor’s web browser when visiting this page. It is often identical to the H

tag (typically the page’s headline). • Canonical URL: Preferred page location or URL to help eliminate duplicate content for search engines. This tells search engines that page in question should be treated as though it were a copy of the listed, and that all of the link and content metrics the engines apply should technically ﬂow back to the listed URL. • Noindex Meta Standard: To prevent most search engine web from indexing a page on IRS.gov, OLS can place a “no index” tag the Metadata Module. This means that external search engines will read the page and will not list it in their results. (

) Use Meta Descriptions and Alt Text process. • The business representative should make sure that all content has abstract, i.e., a brief description of the content. Limit it to one or two sentences. Don’t forget to use keywords. • Alt text describes an image and the function of the image on the Google places a relatively high value on alt text to determine what’s or on an image. All images used must include alt text to improve and comply with accessibility requirements. (

) Site structure represents the Information Architecture for IRS.gov and standards for the internal organization of content and navigation, as well as labeling and categorization to improve content discoverability. (

) Site structure will be maintained through the use of: • Regular content audits • Regular content inventories • Periodic updates to taxonomies • Periodic updates to navigation • Development of additional metadata
Page Meta Descriptions: This is the text that often will appear in results for this page. It must be no longer than

characters and include keywords as appropriate. Each page on IRS.gov should have unique meta description. Page Meta Title: This text displays in the title bar of a visitor’s web browser when visiting this page. It is often identical to the H

tag (typically the page’s headline). Canonical URL: Preferred page location or URL to help eliminate duplicate content for search engines. This tells search engines that page in question should be treated as though it were a copy of the listed, and that all of the link and content metrics the engines apply should technically ﬂow back to the listed URL. Noindex Meta Standard: To prevent most search engine web crawlers from indexing a page on IRS.gov, OLS can place a “no index” tag the Metadata Module. This means that external search engines will read the page and will not list it in their results.
The business representative should make sure that all content has an abstract, i.e., a brief description of the content. Limit it to one or two sentences. Don’t forget to use keywords.

Alt text describes an image and the function of the image on the page. Google places a relatively high value on alt text to determine what’s in or on an image. All images used must include alt text to improve SEO and comply with accessibility requirements.

OLS will maintain a catalog of content types that are available for use in the WCMS. The following table represents some examples of supported content types; it is not a complete list. Revisions to the official catalog of content types will be determined cooperatively between OLS and the business units.

Content Type Description Article Used for creating informative content Landing Page Used for creating new hub pages, such as /ﬁling or /payments Static File Used for hosting static ﬁles for placement in lists and on other pages

) Content Taxonomies: Taxonomies will be managed using the WCMS system. The site will have the following vocabularies: • Focus Area: Broadly categorizing content according to the need it is meant to address • Audience: Identiﬁes the intended audience for a piece of content • Topic: Identiﬁes what a piece of content is about • Guidance Type: Sorts IRS published guidance content by type (e.g. Written Determinations, Revenue Rulings, Chief Counsel Bulletins) (

) Business units may recommend the term(s) that most closely applies to the content. For instance, if a piece of content is written for individual military service members, use the term “military” in the audience vocabulary instead “Individual.” The web strategist will coordinate with the business to ﬁnalize the content tagging. (
) Additional terms may be added to vocabularies in limited cases. If you a need, please contact an OLS web strategist. (

) User experience and design standards greatly inﬂuence the quality of service provided through a website. On IRS.gov, user experience normally compasses the visual presentation of information to the user and the practices for testing and validating the presentation of information to the user.
Content Taxonomies: Taxonomies will be managed using the WCMS taxonomy system. The site will have the following vocabularies:

Focus Area: Broadly categorizing content according to the need it is meant to address Audience: Identiﬁes the intended audience for a piece of content Topic: Identiﬁes what a piece of content is about Guidance Type: Sorts IRS published guidance content by type (e.g. Written Determinations, Revenue Rulings, Chief Counsel Bulletins)
IRS.gov Web Content Management Procedures

) OLS is responsible for optimizing the user experience for IRS.gov website visitors. OLS determines the site design, both at the global level (look and feel) and within the detailed styles established for visual page elements. OLS also determines standards for the site structure (information architecture). See related guidance at IRM
on Site Structure. These standards combine to provide a user-friendly, logical and consistent experience for IRS.gov visitors as they navigate throughout the site. (

) OLS conducts regular analysis of user behavior on IRS.gov to continually monitor the effectiveness of the site design. OLS takes a data-driven approach to identify any problem areas to focus improvements. (

) Business units are responsible for their content on IRS.gov and must ensure that content is technically accurate, up-to-date and relevant for the intended audience. OLS is responsible for the presentation of content items on IRS.gov and determines whether any manually placed visual features (e.g., alert boxes, call outs, etc.) are appropriate. (

) The business representative submits the narrative text required for a webpage through the CMRS. If the request includes proposed visual treatments for the content presentation, the assigned web strategist will review and coordinate with the business representative. If necessary, the web strategist will also coor- dinate design support.

OLS is responsible for optimizing the user experience for IRS.gov website visitors. OLS determines the site design, both at the global level (look and and within the detailed styles established for visual page elements. OLS also determines standards for the site structure (information architecture). See related guidance at IRM
on Site Structure. These standards combine to provide a user-friendly, logical and consistent experience for IRS.gov visitors as they navigate throughout the site.
